fields.headline: Who can vote?
fields.bodyText:  UK nationals who appear on the electoral roll. Not registering for the roll  which is administered by local authorities  is a criminal offence carrying a maximum fine of £1,000.  Under the new Representation of the People Act 2000 several new groups of people will be permitted to vote for the first time: a) a homeless person who has made a "declaration of local connection". This is most likely to be a local day centre, but two enterprising street sleepers have registered themselves at their local park bench. b) People in mental hospitals (other than those with criminal convictions). c) Unconvicted or remand prisoners. They will be able to register in the establishment where they are held if they are likely to be spending a long period remanded in custody. d) People who live on barges (if they list a pub or lock-keeper's house as their roll address). Who cannot vote?  Sitting peers in the House of Lords.  Convicted prisoners (this may be liable to challenge under the recently incorporated Human Rights Act).  Patients in mental hospitals with criminal convictions (this may be liable to challenge under the recently incorporated Human Rights Act).
